item.description:
Barfight! is a fast playing fifteen minute filler card game.

Players take the part of patrons in a typical Fantasy Tavern where the next barfight is just a spilled pint away...

Players draw cards from the Deck which include classic weapons such as Punches, Kicks, Bottles, Chairs, Drinks Trays etc or Dodges, Dodge Behind Victim (lets you pull someone else in the way!) or even Ricochets when an attack bounces off the wall and could go anywhere!

The aim of BARFIGHT! is to be the player who has suffered the least damage when all the cards have been played.

Did you spill my pint...?!

Commander-In-Chief is a fun fast-playing abstract strategy war game published by X Plus Products in which a player's Air, Land and Sea military vehicles work as a unified Armed Forces assault team to "capture" their opponent's Commander. The board consists of a traditional 8 square x 8 square checkerboard grid divided into two Land areas separated by a Sea area. Vehicles are restricted to movement within their assigned battlefields: Through the Air, On Land and/or In the Sea.

Pieces transverse the board in a Chess-like manner. Play evolves, turn by turn, with each player analyzing the current battlefield situation, adjusting their game plan accordingly and executing commands (movements of the playing pieces) in a collective effort to achieve the game's objective. Certain Air pieces (Bombers and Helicopters) can Go Over pieces; likewise certain Sea pieces (Submarines) can Go Under pieces. Additionally, certain pieces (Bombers and Tanks) can Block. The complete Original Release Basic Training Game Rules include "Object of the Game" options, "Team Game Play" options and "Advanced Game Play" options. "Future" options will include new movements, expansion pieces, additional damage control options, new attack features, mini wars and expanded terrains as variants to the Original Release Game Rules.

While this abstract strategy war game does not include random chance, it does allow for piece enhancements both during game play and during board set up which increases come from behind opportunities and can be used to level the playing field between players of various skill levels. The game can be played one-on-one or as a social game with teams. The military theme, the terrain feature of Air, Land and Sea areas of the board and the movements of the pieces themselves relative to the military vehicles they represent give the game a real world appeal.

The two Armed Forces consist of the following fifteen pieces per side: one Commander, two stealth Fighters, two army Tanks, one stealth Bomber, two submersible Submarine warships, two Helicopters, four amphibious assault vehicles (Amphibians) and one surface combatant Destroyer warship. This military themed board game, representing two Armed Forces, "Supports Our Troops" as the game of the "Y" by donating $1 to the Armed Services YMCA for every game sold.

Commander-In-Chief is a 3-In-1 board game that includes Chess & Checkers; these Classics are played on the dark and light colored side of the double sided game board. Additional game play options include: Tic-Tac-Toe and The Triangle Puzzle Game. Lastly, the 30 pieces that come with the game are miniatures, 30 Military Toys, designed for play with or without this board game and the 30 bases that the miniatures mount on, when inverted, become 30 Stackable Spinning Tops designed for multiple family fun games.

name.value: Kunitori! Kessen: The Battle of Moegahara

item.description:
In Kunitori! Kessen: The Battle of Moegahara, you are one of the feudal lords taking part in the grand battle of Moegahara, where the lands are to be divided. Joining forces with either East or West, you must use your finances and deploy your forces wisely, while keeping a keen eye on your enemy's moves.

Kunitori! Kessen: The Battle of Moegahara is set in the same world as the other Kunitori! titles, but is a standalone game for two, four or six players that cannot be used as an expansion for those games. Players form two teams; each player starts with a deck of eight cards and gradually buys more cards from the card pool to add to his army. Eventually the armies are deployed to the front line, where the two teams compete for a majority of the land cards displayed there.

name.value: Gensokyo itazura daisakusen: Eiki-sama no gyakuten saiban

item.description:
A bluffing game for 3–10 players (6 or more preferred).

The game consists of a deck of of cards, representing ten different practical jokes. The cards are all dealt to the players who then play out these practical jokes on each other, face down, claiming aloud it's of a specific kind. The player who is hit can either call it (a lie or the truth) or send the practical joke on to another player. If a player calls it and is wrong, he gains the practical joke card(s) as penalty points (not added to his hand) and also gains a power card that he can use for his benefit later in the game.

The game ends when one player runs out of cards, at which point all cards in hand are added as penalty points. The player with the least penalty point wins.

The art in this game is all based on characters from the Project Shrine Maiden, a series of home-made shooting games for Windows.

item.description:
A set-collecting card game with auctioned turn order, based on characters and situations from Project Shrine Maiden, a series of amateur shooting games for Windows.

Gensokyo ritual comes in independent two-deck packages, which all can be played separately with 2–4 players or together with more players.

Players are dealt a number of "liquor" cards. Each turn, a number of character cards and event cards are drawn and revealed, and the turn order is auctioned out using these liquor cards. Players then gain one character card of their choice from the ones displayed and may also try to complete any of the face up event cards. The Event are the cards that are worth victory points, and in order to gain them, the player must discard the number of character cards mentioned on the event card.

As there never is any hand renewal of the liquor cards, they must be use wisely.

User summary:

A light-weight card game, a version of UNO, based on characters from Project Shrine Maiden, a series of amateur shooting games for Windows.

Of a deck consisting of coloured cards numbered 0–9 and some cards with special effects, players are dealt 7 cards each. A card from the deck is drawn and placed on the table, and the starting player may then only play a card from his hand that matches number or colour. If he can't, he must draw a card from the deck. Play goes on until someone managed to get rid of all his cards and thus wins.

Of the cards with special effects, there are cards that change the turn order, cards that jump the next player's turn, cards that forces the next player to draw cards, wild cards that change colour, counter cards that counter whatever the latest effect was, and so on.

About every single card has a unique illustration.

Goal: Be third on target to win

1. Each player chooses 2 (plastic) frogs (same colour)
2. Try to reach as quick as possible (rolling the dice by turns) the marked (dead) zone 
3. Try to optimize (by dice) your position(s) for the final leap 
4. Cross the target on third position

It reproduces the development of a race of motorbike of the duration of 4 turns.
Every player chooses a motorbike and takes the relative card with tachometer.
Using of the cards movement he moves himself to us along the distance. Who wins arrives for first to the goal.
Contained: map he represents a track, cards, 4 motorbike in plastic, 4 cards with tachometer and handbook.

The game includes a large white plastic bowl and lots of colorful plastic pieces of spaghetti that fit around the top rim of the bowl. Three S'getti meatballs are placed on the spaghetti. Children remove the spaghetti pieces one by one without letting the meatballs fall through to the bottom when the bowl upsets and spills the spaghetti and meatballs on the table. The player who causes the meatball to fall in the pot is the loser.

Goal: Be the first to get rid of all taken 'Dominoes'-cards

Game consists of 2 black/red dice and 78 cards, which show two different sides - halfway through
printed in red and black with symbols from 1 to 6, infrequently a joker.

1. Each player draws 6 cards
2. Roll the dice: If someone owns a card with matching symbols he/she may start putting this side up in the middle of the table. If no one has a matching card all the players must draw an additional one and roll the dice again.
3. Now proceed adding your cards by turn according 'Dominoes', but you must roll the dice first or you choose the dice result of your predecessor: Only the those numbers can be placed with matching numbers to cards on the table AND on the dice; a Joker may be placed at any combination. During your turn you may add further cards, which have to match with cards on the table only.
4. If you have finished your turn draw a new card from the pile
5. Check the dice results of the other players carefully; if you possess a matching card the turn is yours, as long as you are quick enough
6. Placing your last card on the table - you win

Goal: Be the first who achieves a predefined pattern with your plugs

1. Each player gets 5 coloured plugs
2. Players choose a (predefined) pattern (on a 6 x 6 matrix)
3. Put all your plugs by turns into the holes
4. Move your plugs - you may not jump over - thus you can block your opponent
5. Create the required pattern and win

Game description from the publisher:

Fantastic treasure lies deep within the Dungeon of Dread, but to find it you must survive a deadly gauntlet. Heroes band together to form adventuring parties and face off against monsters and villains in the dungeon—but the adventure doesn't end there!

Dungeon of Dread is an exciting, cooperative board game experience in which heroes unite in battle to achieve a common goal and defeat the enemies standing in their way. If they succeed, glory and fortune will be theirs for the taking. If they fail, all could be lost!

This cooperative board game experience is designed for 2-5 players, ages 10 and up. One player is the Dungeon Master who runs the villains and monsters; the remaining players are the heroes. The game includes four adventures, each one featuring a unique villain.

Update, August 11, 2011

Apparently Dungeon of Dread was not as "exciting" as Wizards of the Coast hoped for, as the company announced at Gen Con 2011 that the title was no longer scheduled for release.

Metapontum is a cooperative abstract strategy game created and promoted by Dutch designer Hans Theo Frenkel and the foundation he created, for the purpose of promoting world peace. It is played on an 8x8 hexagonal board with 16 pieces on each side, that have movement very similar to those in Chess, and are abstract as in Chess. The goal of Metapontum is for both sides to exchange their pieces from their chosen opening setup to their chosen end setup in a minimum amount of moves. On every turn, a player can either move one of his pieces or exchange one of his pieces with one of his opponent's, as long as his piece has line of sight to the other.

Frenkel's web site sells various game boards made out of either cardboard, wood or stone. Frenkel claims that all games are produced under fair trade practices.

User summary:
A basic set of skirmish-level miniatures rules for urban combat between street gangs, law enforcement, special forces, etc. Game scale is 1:1 with each figure representing individual fighters, vehicles, etc. Each turn equals 5 seconds of "real" time and the ground scale is 1.5 centimeters equals 1 meter. These rules are intended for use with 28-30mm miniatures but could easily be adapted to smaller scales. Individual models are assigned individual skill levels (Streetwise, Brawling, Ranged Combat) and are given an allotment of Option Points to further customize each figure. Players equip each of their forces based on an Equipment Points system which allows them to add weapons, ammo, and miscellaneous equipment. Combat rules cover close combat, ranged, and special weapons such as RPGs and other heavy arms.

From the introduction:
'Street F.M.' is designed to represent small-scale conflict in a modern or near future urban environment. By employing scale models to represent the combatants and their surroundings it is possible to create clashes between street gangs, criminals, law enforcers and small military units. In fact any group entering urban combat, armed with everything from improvised weapons through to rocket launchers can be covered by the system.

There has been a zombie outbreak! The cameras focus in a small town, where a band of cliché characters has holed up, waiting for rescue. It never comes. Worse still, the zombies continue to grow in number and intelligence. A conclusion is drawn: If the characters wish to survive, they must make a break for the outskirts and escape the town. Will anyone be left when the credits roll?

PostHumousZ is a team based zombie survival horror game. Each player controls a single human character or horde of themed zombies. A modular town is randomly laid out each game, with the safe house at one end and the escape on the other. Likewise, every character and zombie theme is randomly generated by combining 3 cards giving each player, and team, its own strengths and weaknesses.

The humans must move through the town to the escape, collecting items, rescuing nameless survivors (extras), fighting zombies, and hiding at strategic moments. Zombies killed by the characters are taken as points, and are spent to activate abilities and buy powerful plot changing cards (H-cards). The zombies in turn spawn and direct the undead, collect hunger (zombies’ resource) and use their cards and abilities to overwhelm the humans before they escape. Unlike the humans, the zombies’ plot cards (Z-cards) are drawn freely over time as well as purchased, meaning the clock is against the living. Gameplay is dynamic as both teams are affected by random events and changes in their opponents’ strategy.

PostHumousZ 295 unique cards add near endless variation, depth, drama and humor to each game, while simple base rules and bold art make it quick to learn, easy to keep track of, and low on downtime.

item.description: A 3M EduPLAYtional game. A "schoolhouse" holds cards that show basic math problems. Insert the key (a peg) into the hole with the correct answer and the card will slide free. Pick the wrong answer and the card is held in place. A very simple educational game, the math version of Teach Key Reading and Spelling.

With a spin of the wheel, you must tell your secrets or take the challenge! Game makes childern act out or dance various Barbie scenerios, such as "Reciting a favorite Poem", Doing a 1 Minute Aerobic Routine, Changing Barbie's clothes in 30 Seconds or trying to do different dance routines. Try to Collect Cards w/Barbie Fashions, Cars & Other Accessories to Win! Sounds easy, right? However, a spink of the Barbie Wheel tells you if first you must tell a secret or perform a Barbie Challenge, such as Accepting an Award lik Superstar Barbie.

Components:

 random spinning wheel, 
 25 What To Wear cards, 
 25 Going In Style cards, 
 25 Places to Go cards, 
 5 Ken cards,
The Inscrutable Game of Skill and Luck. The object of the game is to guide all the marbles, one at a time, into the hole in the game center, and score the most points in each round

Typical game of Battleship that adds 3 planes, which have no particular special skills. Each player places two grids side by side. In the first grid, hidden by a screenplay depicting the world, he has to place his units, while in the second one he will place some chips showing the coordinates of the shots fired. The player who first hits all the enemy units wins.

This game is based on a tv quiz show broadcast in Italy. A player will play the presenter, while the others the competitors. The game develops in 3 contests: the Curtain, where players in turn try to guess the character hidden by 16 tiles removing as few ones as possible, the Poll, where players try to guess the exact percentage of a national poll and the Big Quiz, where players try to answer a question on a exclusive selected subject between news, culture, science, show business, sport and advertising. Finally, each player has to answer to a question choosing between three different categories, namely music, history or literature/sport/show business, in order to double his own score or lose all the points scored. The player with the highest score, wins.

This game is based on a tv quiz show broadcast in Italy. A player will play the presenter, while the others the competitors trying to answer questions on movie, music and sport subjects. The game develops in 2 phases. In the first phase, players collect points according to the difficulty of the trial by answering the questions or guessing the caricature of famous characters; in the second one, each player will have to answer to a number of questions on a subject chosen between movie, music and sport equal to the collected score divided by 3; for each correct answer, the player earns 3 millions £. The player who scores higher wins.

item.description:
The Speedy Scramble for Slugs and Bugs!

Bug Cards are scattered all over your table or even your living room floor! Players race to capture the bugs by covering each Bug Card with a matching Leaf Card--It's a wild scramble to find each bug! Be the first player to cover all of your matching Bug Cards and Bug Out!

Sealed with a Kiss is a game where girls collect kisses (yes, kisses!) on their boyfriend's photos. It works like this: Every player gets one of 12 boyfriend photos (these guys are hunks!). Anyway, put the photos in the frames and move around the game board collecting kisses. When you win a kiss, you use the special 'kisser' stamper to stamp your boyfriend's photo. But hey, life's not always great, is it? Sometimes you can lose kisses, take kisses, or even have to trade boyfriends. The first player to collect five kisses wins the game. It’s that easy and tons of fun!

60 cards, featuring Goods Cards, Conveyance Cards and Obstruction Cards.
It is a trick-taking game really, but quite advanced for its age. The first player in any round must offer a Goods Card. The next player may offer a Conveyance Card, suitable for carrying the Goods on offer. If he does, he collects the Goods Card. The third player may play an Obstruction to this arrangement and snaffle the Goods himself.
The winner is the player who collects the highest tonnage of Goods.

The Crazy Credit Card Game!
Charge It! plays like real life. Big spenders bargain hunters and cash savers all have fun shopping and spending rolling the dice and moving around the board. Vacations, TVs and concert tickets are just a few of the possibilities to charge when players qualify for the Quik Charge, American Success, Recover and Bold Credit Cards.

Decide how to divide the payday cash between expenses, credit card debts or savings. Shoppers beware - it is easy to get caught in the alluring trap of unlimited purchasing power. Debts can pile up and the bank may revoke credit cards if payments are not made on time.

The object of Charge is to acquire the right combination of "paid up" credit cards, purchased items and cash. There may be some players who believe it is un-wise to have many credit cards. Some may fail to get good credit. These players may choose to win with one credit card, one purchased Item and $4,000 cash. Can you guess how the other players will try to win? Have fun!

Players lays the tiles on the gameboard playing:
Gin Rummy, Canasta, Poker, Fan Tan, Black Jack and Solitaire.
Some bonus squares in the game board are marked as cards and if players place the tile to any of this bonus squares they recieve high score.

Components:

 game board
 108 tiles, equal to two decks of cards, plus four jokers 
 4 tile racks.

After the death of Yonaguska, the Cherokee tribe meets to select a new leader. As always with the Native Americans, the wise elders have the most influence and occupy the highest positions in the hierarchy. Due to their old age, however, they are also vulnerable to the youngsters, who want to take their place and will not hesitate to challenge their opponents. Which clan can obtain the most feathers and thus select the new leader?

In Cherokee, players try to occupy the most and highest positions in the hierarchy with their clan members. On a turn, a player chases away one member in the pyramid of cards, which represents the hierarchy of the tribe. This gap is then filled with one successor from below, with that gap being filled likewise. At the end of a turn, the player adds one card from his hand to the final gap in the base of the pyramid.

Cherokee is a game of paranoia – which colors are your enemies?

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Hordes of dark minions have descended upon the countryside, eager to secure their reputation as a scourge on mankind. The despicable evil marauders attack everywhere in search of conquest. The citizens are helpless and will soon be overwhelmed. Death and destruction awaits all those in the path of the evil ones.

In Dark Minions players represent those forces of evil as they try to pillage and destroy towns. Each turn, the players typically roll three dice and may use the resulting numbers to attack Towns to win Vanquish Points (VPs) – the further along into the game, the more VPs the Towns are worth. Players also attempt to capture Towers in order to level up experience (which enables the player to roll better dice), to re-spawn dead minions from the graveyard, and to "purchase" the services of the various Overlords. In the end, it's all about VPs and the first player to 40 VPs in a four-player game wins.

The advanced game adds 15 Minion Overlords, each with a unique special power that may affect the play or the outcome of the game. They patiently wait to enter play and wreak their terrible havoc. Using their abilities wisely is one of the many keys to victory.

Dark Minions includes a small expansion called Demon Lords that adds more Overlords, a special town tile, and a special die – making for many ways to mix up the game play!

item.description:
Based on the classic midway arcade game, the object of Hot Shot Basketball game is to either score the most points in 60 seconds or score 10 baskets in the least amount of time. The game features switch positions and buttons on the backboard that give you lots of options to "put it up" for points!

You can choose between 2 skill levels and 2 games...and choose whether or not you want sound effects!

For 1 or more players.

item.description:
From the box:
All You have to do is to put a ring on that funny little tin ring fixed to the ring and the press down the spring with Your finger and let it go suddenly. Up goes the ring and it falls on that pretty board with different colored divisions. If the ring falls into one of the 6 divisions it scores the number marked thereon. If You are lucky Your ring falls over the peg and then, You score the number of points marked in the centre. It is real fun to see who can score the highest number in a certain number of rounds.

Baseball simulation game, teams perform realistically.

From the publishers website:

A perfect complement to Replay Baseball for solo replay projects. FastScore Baseball allows the Replayer to quickly play out a whole day's schedule of games, including realistic scores, in just minutes!

It's a quick play game that generates the score of a baseball game with a few rolls of the dice. The game incorporates ease of play, a simple ratings system and simple charts. Play to relax, no complicated mental gymnastics required.

Fastscore Baseball is played using two differently colored 6-sided dice. Each team has three ratings- an offensive, defensive and clutch rating. Better ratings are color coded in green while worse ratings are color coded in red. Higher offense ratings represent teams with punishing offenses. Lower defense ratings represent teams that give up fewer runs. Higher clutch ratings represent better team performance in close games.

If you play Fastscore as a stand-alone game, you can finish a season replay in a few hours! You can also use Fastscore Baseball as a complement to detailed, play by play games like Replay Baseball. If you are enjoying a single team replay, play your favorite team’s games with Replay while playing out the other games on the schedule with Fastscore, and see how your team is doing in the standings! A full day’s worth of games can be completed in a minute!

Fastscore offers great value for the gamer. Each Fastscore set includes multiple seasons for one low price! We Every season from 1950 to the current day is rated.

Each season includes:

 Scoring Charts
 One single-page chart
 One two-sided chart for two-page printing
 (same chart data, in two formats for printing) 
 
 Team Ratings Chart
 Starting Pitchers Ratings
 As-Played Schedule with starting pitchers and pre-calculated game ratings for each team

From the publisher's website:

A perfect complement to Second Season Football for solo replay projects. FastScore Football allows the Replayer to quickly play out a whole day's schedule of games, including realistic scores, in just minutes!

It's a quick play game that generates the score of a football game with a few rolls of the dice. It incorporates ease of play, a simple ratings system and simple charts. Hundreds of simulated seasons are run, ensuring the accuracy of each Fastscore season while factoring in each team’s strength of schedule.

Although the ratings seem simple, there is a great deal of background information packed into each rating. This game uniquely takes into account the offensive and defensive styles of each team by separating scoring frequency and scoring ability. For example, some teams may score frequently, but fail to execute in the red zone- thus adding points to the board with field goals more frequently than touchdowns. Others may rarely score but efficiently march into the endzone- thus scoring more touchdowns than field goals. Additionally, offensive and defensive strengths in the running and passing game are reflected in the ratings and will influence the score of the game. For example, teams with strong defenses against the run will more effectively shut down teams that rely on the running game. And in close games, give your team a fighting chance by going for a 2-pt conversion!

With Fastscore football, teams will perform similarly to their real-life stats in points for and against, touchdowns for and against, field goals for and against, and most importantly, their win-loss record. These stats are fine-tuned to a 250-season average typically within 10 points of actual, and within 2 TDs and FGs of actual. Strength of schedule is factored into the ratings to ensure the utmost in accuracy.

And the best part: we’ve included the as-played schedule for each season! And we didn’t stop there- we know that your time is valuable, so we’ve calculated the final team ratings for each game on the schedule- taking into account home field advantage and the run/pass ratings- so you don’t have to do the calculations yourself. Just sit back, roll the dice and mark down the score of the game.

Fastscore Football is played using two differently colored 6-sided dice. Each team has seven ratings representing offensive and defensive abilities and a clutch rating. Better ratings are color coded in green while worse ratings are color coded in red. Higher offense ratings represent teams with punishing offenses. Lower defense ratings represent teams that effectively shut down their opponents.

If you play Fastscore as a stand-alone game, you can finish a season replay in a few hours! You can also use Fastscore Football as a complement to detailed, play by play games like Second Season Football. If you are enjoying a single team replay, play your favorite team’s games with your favorite football game while playing out the other games on the schedule with Fastscore, and see how your team is doing in the standings! A week’s worth of games can be completed in less than 15 minutes!

Fastscore offers great value for the gamer. Each Fastscore set includes multiple seasons for one low price! We intend to rate every season from current day to the seasons of yesteryear.

Each season includes: 

 Rules of the game
 Scoring Charts
 Team Ratings Chart
 As-Played Schedule with pre-calculated game ratings for each team

Armored Knights, starts with Operation Gazelle, the battle of the Israeli offensive to cross the Suez Canal and invade Africa and cut off the Egyptian Army elements that were on the east side of the canal. This series focus is on combat at the battalion level on a scale that makes representing large battles real fun. It will also have its own innovative and unique way to handle the combat mutlipliers for engineers, anti-tank, intelligence, and recon elements. The players will find this does not always work the way they want and the support troops sometimes fail to do the mission they are assigned to do. They might even have a detrimental effect.

Grognard Simulations continues to think of new ways to make the players do some critical thinking before committing troops to take positions and engage in combat. Providing the support that will give them the edge (rolling well also helps) is the key to maximizing combat strengths for each side. The Israeli's are outnumbered somewhat, but the Egyptians have some serious restrictions given they did not want to believe the threat was credible. This gave the Israelis time to eliminate the Egyptian air defenses and get their superior air power into the battle.

Incredible Courage at Austerlitz - Telnitz is GSI's first offering on Napoleonic warfare. The game focuses on tactical level combat and maneuver during the Battle of Austerlitz in December 1805.
The game features variable combat strengths. Turns are 10 minutes of time.   The rules are modeled around the seven battlefield operating systems which make them easily understood and easy to learn.  Unlike other games at this level the rules will not be massive.  Troop replacements are generated by returning stragglers to the battle.  A few features are variable combat strengths, elite units, and levels of order.  Units start with a certain amount of these and as they lose them their abilities are reduced.
Buxhowden came down off the Pratzen Heights to attack the French right since it was so weak.  Little did he know that while this was true at 0700 in the morning the Iron Marshall, Davout, would arrive shortly and provide the bulwark against which the defense would halt and then throw back the Coalition forces.

Similar to the Death Ride series this game is the first of many that wplayers will be able to build into a larger monster of the Austerlitz battle. Again critical thinking will allow the players to figure out the correct formations and deployment of their troops. Infantry units are modeled at the company level, cavalry at the squadron level, and artillery at the section level. The rules for this detailed game will surprise you with their clarity and brevity.

item.description:
The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the gameboard from a Residence Square to the shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with travel cards for all locations on his shopping list wins the game!

Game board is map of Albany, NY depicting roads, highways, places of interest, businesses and billboards. Businesses used this game as an advertisement. Came with coupons for businesses advertised.

Panic in the web! Two spider clans are fighting each other in an epic duel! Spiders in bigger groups will defeat the weakest in the intersections of the web.

A thrilling and challenging strategy game, where players attack and capture their opponent's spiders.

The goal is to capture three of your opponent's spiders. On each turn you can either place a spider on the board on one of the intersections of your color, or move a spider anywhere on the board onto an intersection of your color. Spiders are captured when a spider is outnumbered orthogonally by spiders of the opposite color.

Players pick cards from the draw deck and make decisions based on the information given on each card. Document your decisions on your Game Sheet and move your Player Piece on the Board.

Some of the Choices You Will Make: Is it the right time to buy a car? How will I pay for college? Should I start a part time business? Should I pay for those concert tickets with cash or use my credit card? etc.

Thrive Score measures the decisions you make in the game.
Good decisions = positive Thrive; poor decisions = negative Thrive. Everyone starts out with a zero Thrive Score (Survive).

You WIN if your Player who's game piece reaches Thrive first wins the game.

A fast-action race game for younger children, based on the lovable Walt Disney Robin Hood film characters.
A simple dice-rolling game. The object is to get your men safely to Nottingham Castle.

Colour and shape matching form the basis of this fun game as players compete to see who can make the l-o-n-g-e-s-t caterpillar (see image to see children playing the game). A spinner decides which card you may take and then you must try to fit it into your caterpillar.

A card game where have to build a crossword puzzle.

The game contains 100 cards, each one as one or two letters printed on it. 4 cards are drawn and put on the table in a row. The rest of the cards are shuffled, divided by the players and put in front of them as individual stacks.

On your turn, you draw cards from your stack until you have 7 in your hand and try to add them to the existing words already on the table in a crossword puzzle style. You may cover existing cards (therefore the name of the game); only rows are required to be meaningful words, columns can be any letters you like.

If you manage to create a new word, you score the points according to its length and the next player takes his turn. The game ends when one player has only one or no more cards to play.

Goal: Be the first who concentrates your meeples with a majority of 3 on one of the big yellow circuits

1. Each player places one of his/her coloured meeple on each big yellow circuit (16)
2. Move your meeples by turn along the small yellow circuits - jumping is not allowed; capacity on a small circuit: max 1 meeple; - on a big circuit: max 7 meeples
3. You win if the achieved majority is 3:0, 4:1 or 5:2

Goal: Be the first who has captured 4 foxes

1 Hunters and foxes are placed on the tagged spaces of the board
2 Players roll the die by turn and try to catch a fox; you may move horizontal, vertical or 
 diagonal, but not in combination - excact number, jumping not allowed
3 Jump on the fox if you roll appropiate number
4 With appropiate number you may jump on an opponent's hunter if he carries one or more foxes 
 - he is sent back to his base immidiately
5 Foxes delivered to the base are safe

Goal: Be the first who fills up all 7 empty own target spaces

1. Each player places all meeples on his/her base
2. Roll the 2 dice by turns - with a '6' you have to put one of your meeples on the starting area
3. Move your meeple(s) by rolling the dice - you may use either one die or the other 
4. Catching an opponent => you aquired a prisoner you may use for to fill up your targets, too
5. Rolling a double you catch all meeples on a line (bridge) - you may choose - at once

"Challenge your memory and test your luck as you race to collect seven Bible verses over seven rounds and win the game!
Learn what the Bible says about the creation as you lay down one completed verse per hand. Then discard key words from the verses to outscore your opponents. If you can't complete the verse before the round ends, you must try, try again!"

Each round, players attempt to collect a set of four numbered, color coded cards that complete a Bible verse. This is done by drafting and discarding. Once a complete verse has been collected the player then lays down their set and tries to go out as soon as possible by discarding their remaining cards on other players' sets. Keyword cards and other action cards add an extra twist to the gameplay. At the end of each round, points are 'awarded' based on remaining cards-in-hand, and after seven rounds the lowest scorer wins!

name.value: À l'abordage: Jeu officiel des pirates

item.description:
In this dexterity game you and the other three captains have to manage your crew, and put those lazy pirates at work! The objective of the game is to carefully put all your crew members (represented by plastic stand shaped on a mighty pirate form, in four colours) on the ship, on the right colored level randomized by a spin weel. But be careful... The ships its's moving a lot! If you make other figures fall out of the ship, you have to take those in your crew!
Only the best captain will put all his men on the ship, and win the game.

The game of baseball has been played for many years in many forms. The term "Lords of Baseball" refers to the moguls on the business end of the game. The people who make the decisions and cut the paychecks have been made into symbols of greed and of ferocity. In Lords of Baseball, you will take on the role of one of these owners. You will need to build an entire organization, not just a Major League team.

Baseball Hall-of-Famer Tommy Lasorda once said of the game, "No matter how good you are, you're going to lose one-third of your games. No matter how bad you are you're going to win one-third of your games. It's the other third that makes the difference."

In Lords of Baseball, your record is based on this principle. Do you have what it takes to sustain a dynasty? Will you build your team through trades or through a strong farm system? With multiple paths to victory, Lords of Baseball will give you that chance. It’s not only about winning the World Series, it’s also about doing the little things that will help you score Victory Points and at the end of 20 years make you the Lord of Baseball.

Lords of Baseball is a card driven game where players take control of a fictional organization and build it from the ground up. They will invest money into a Farm System, Front Office, and Field Manager in an attempt to build a dynasty. Over the course of 5 seasons, owners will use these investments to score Victory Points. These investments will not only score VP's for owners, but also give them certain privileges during game play.

Each year is broken down into 4 phases: Spring Training, Regular Season, Postseason, and Winter Meetings. Player decisions will go a long way towards seeing how well the team fares during the season. If the team with the best record has enough wins to win the pennant, that team moves on to a World Series phase that allows them to earn more VP.

name.value: City of Brass: a game of colonial exploration

item.description:
from the introduction:
The Expedition Afrique

In 1892, the French led a military campaign in Dahomey, the "Slave Coast" between Nigeria and Togo, against its kings so that they might have control of Porto Novo, a coastal city. They marched all the way to Abomey, the capital of the land, and found the rulers gone. They amused themselves by looting the city for souvenirs. The French press was most impressed by a white parasol decorated with human jawbones.

They never saw the inside of that parasol. Inside it was a map drawn in human blood, a map that pointed to a legendary city deep in Afrca's interior. This city was called the City of Brass, a bastion of ancient African civilization full of treasure, both gold and knowledge.

Sadi Carnot, the president of France, sent a expedition on that doomed journey. It only took three weeks for them to become hopelessly lost in an uncharted land. To this day, no one knows what happened to them. According to legend, only one of them made it, and his greatest wishes were given unto him.

In this game, you will play those lost souls. Trapped in Africa's interior, with a map drawn on a parasol and not enough resources, you search.

A note about the content of this game

While there is no magic in this game, it is a fantasy. The nobility found among the people of Africa is not balanced against the savagery found here. Like all peoples, the historic Africans had both high nobility and awful destruction found in them. Even though this game depicts the negative side of culture disproportionally, the author is fully aware that is not the only side, or even the dominant side.

User summary:
This game is a form of highly abstracted, limited scope role-playing game with a fixed set of characters and goals.

Each player takes one of 6 different pre-defined characters: the Explorer, the Official, the Doctor, the Priest, the Naturalist, and the Native Guide. A minimum of 4 players is recommended and one player must play the Explorer. The Explorer nominates the Leader and the Leader selects a Companion. The Leader narrates the obstacles that face the expedition.

Each player must name their character (a French sounding name is recommended) and answer the question: what does your character seek in the City of Brass.

Each character has 6 predefined statistics and each Ability has a corresponding Resource that replenishes it . The Resources are drawn from a deck of resource cards during play.

The game is divided in 5 Acts, in each of the first four Acts there are 5 Obstacles. The fifth act is the City of Brass and final scoring is done at the end of this act.

Points are scored by defeating the obstacles and players may help one another during play, but are free to refuse help. Obstacles are defeated by rolling a pool of dice against the target set by the Leader for that obstacle. The number of dice rolled is determined by the Ability that is required to defeat it.

Each player totals their Quest Points earned during play and plays out the endgame story. The endgame has a blind voting/bluff mechanism that offers a point bonus based on player voting, bluffing is possible during the vote count.

At the end of play, the player with the most points is the winner. Ties are possible.

Jokk means "all is correct in legally" in Estonia.

There are a 101 colored spaces in gameboard where players move.from 1 to 101.
1-40 spaces are for local level
41-82 spaces are for state level
83-100 spaces are for upper class level

In his turn player roll the die, move his pawn and draw a card same color as space he stands. Different colors mean different categories of questions: Varia, Local, State, Internatinal, President. Player who answer correctly gives 1 point. Wrong answer gives -1 point.
Player may move to next higer level if he has at least 5 points to give or he must take another round to get more points.
Player who reach first in 101th "Jokk" area wins the game.

A Rules-light Print'n'play tabletop strategy game for 1 or more players, Phantom Capsule revolves around piloting middle-sized robots in defense of a city plagued by monsters.
The game pieces are all constructable papercrafts.
All game-pieces and rules are free and available for download.

Gameplay centers around logistics, in that players decide what to focus their robot's precious energy on before the actual action phase begins.
The monsters operate on rudimentary AI, and largely govern themselves.

The goal of each mission is variable, but typically the player/players must work together to defend a single power plant from invaders. There are also rules for direct competition between players, which gets messy very quickly.

item.description: A cartoon-watching game designed to teach children to observe carefully while watching TV. Kids search each cartoon for a series of objects or characters shown on their hand of playing cards or on the game board. The first to spot them all is the winner.

Apostles is a card game for 2-4 players. Players compete to be the first to play out their entire hand of cards in numerical order, while alternating colors, onto any of the four starting piles. Simon/Peter(#1) cards can start new piles in the corners of the gameplay area. Based on the classic game "King's Corners", Apostles is a fun way to learn about the 12 Apostles.

Great for Sunday Schools, Youth Groups and Family Game Nights. Part of the Sporadic Games Educational Line.

item.description:
Become the leader of an imp family that has just started a new business – breeding and selling petz. Sound simple and safe? Well, we forgot to mention that those petz are for Dungeon Lords. This means magical, playful, sometimes angry monsters that constantly desire attention and at the very moment you want them to demonstrate their qualities to buyers they are sick or they poop. Sometimes you are even glad that you got rid of them – but the profit is unbelievable.

Dungeon Petz is a standalone game set in the Dungeon Lords universe. The game consists of several rounds in which players use unusual worker placement mechanisms (players simultaneously prepare different sized groups of imps in order to play sooner than others) to prepare themselves for the uneasy task of raising creature cubs and pleasing their different needs (represented by cards) in order to sell them as grown and scary creatures to Dungeon Lords. In the meantime, they also attend various contests in which they show off their pets, scoring additional points.

name.value: Fair Trade: A Game of Competitive Coffee Cartels

item.description:
Fair Trade: A Game of Competitive Coffee Cartels is a light economic game simulating supply and demand in the fair trade market. Players make contracts with growers, sell coffee to their market, and improve their operation in order to satisfy the cravings of addicts the world over.

On each turn a player does the following:

1) Draw three coffee cubes from a bag containing equal amounts of coffee cubes. Add them to the demand meters in the center of the board.
2) "Make contracts" with growers from the four corners of the world by moving each grower marker up or down on the contract grid in front of you.
3) The growers then grow coffee. Each player draws one cube for each region he/she has contracts with. The amount of contracts made for that region as well as the type of cube drawn determines how much coffee you get.
4) The player has the option to advertise specific types of coffee, thus potential increasing demand for their stock.
5) Players then may sell their coffee, making more for coffees in higher demand. Selling coffee reduces demand for that coffee in their region.

Because there is a set amount of cubes in the bag, players must balance supply and demand to stay on top.

Fair Trade: A Game of Competitive Coffee Cartels is the first in a line of "Green" games by I-55 Games (a non-profit publisher aimed to provide workplace re-entry training in St. Louis). These games are all hand manufactured and made with almost entirely re-purposed material.

item.description: Arrr! is a semi-cooperative pirate game where the players control pirates on a ship and try to board the enemy, get treasures and gold and don't get sunk. Internal struggles forces munitys and backstabbing but the players can only survive as a team. If the ship sinks, all players lost, if the game ends, the player with the most gold in his treasurechest wins.

Auction Junktion is a storage auction game in which the players use auction, bluffing and other underhanded skills to win the best treasures while leaving everyone else wallowing in useless junk!

When storage lockers go unpaid or abandoned, the property goes up for auction to the highest bidder!

Each auction is played out with several face down cards drawn representing items in a storage locker. Each player only gets to peek at one item but you are bidding on the entire set. Be careful, because many of the items are worthless junk! Sift your way through the trash to find the hidden treasures!

You’ve got to use all the bargaining skills you have to beat out the competition as well as good bluffing skills to get the other players to buy all the junk.

It’s all about the money; will you have it all at the end or will you be wallowing in a big pile of junk?

(NOTE: This game does not intend to depict real world prices for items found in storage units. This game is for entertainment purposes only.)

Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe is a game that is about investing in combinations of the most profitable companies to earn the most money. The game models the westward expansion of railroads from the East Coast all the way to the Pacific. Players begin with a set number of cubes which they can choose to invest as shares, expand railroad networks, add to the value of resources or add resources to railroads. Like colors for railroads doubles income at railroad stops. Each railroad has a varied amount of stops and resource combinations to ensure that every game is different. When two adjacent starting railroads have fully developed their routes, the second stage of railroads opens up and dividends are issued to the first and second majority owners matching that company color. The game progresses until all players pass or there are no more valid moves to be made. A final dividend is triggered and the player with the most money wins.

Use your armies wisely and conquer the world!. A dice rolling combat based wargame, in which you place your armies in different places of the world map and fight the other players over total domination. In essence, a risk clone.

item.description:
Each player tries to complete a row of five numbered cards with one kind of precious stone. 
There are four kinds of stones. Each player secretly has a kind of stone that s/he collects, and a row of five face-down cards in front of him/her. In a turn, a player takes a card from another player and looks at it. If it is the kind of stone s/je is looking for, s/he places the card face-down in front of him/her (in the right position, 1-5). If it is a different kind of stone, the card can go to any of the other positions. In any case the card that was in that position before goes to the position of the card that was drawn. 
A player who reveals what kind of stone s/he is looking for gets two bonus moves. 
The first player to complete the row of five cards of his/her preferred kind in the right order is the winner.

The game was published in WIN - Das Spielejournal 418 in January 2011.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

There is no date on the rules but the style of the graphics and shape of the vehicles suggest post 1945 and likely to be in the early 1950's.

The mechanics of the game is similar in style to ludo/pachisi but involves moving both a pedestrian and a vehicle from Home to Base to win. The four routes around the board intercept each other. The pedestrian dodge the motorists to avoid being knocked down and sent to hospital. The vehicles avoid the pedestrians as well as the police car to avoid being sent to prison.

A die is thrown and as you move along your route you hope to avoid landing on the many penalty square which may throw you into the path of other players' vehicles or pedestrians

Every time a 6 is thrown the police car is moved to try and catch jaywalkers and cars

Per the back of the box

Based on the bestselling novels by Vadim Panov. Fairytales and chilling nightmares have become reality on the streets of Moscow. Take control over on of the Secret City's Great Houses and embark on the path of fights and intrigue! Conquer enemy territories, assemble armies, purchase mysterious artifacts, cast deadly spells and summon the greatest heroes of your House to aid you in your quest to assume total control over the Secret City.

Secret City is based on the eponymous series of books by Vadim Panov and tells the story of another Moscow, home to the last representatives of long lost civilizations, and in particular - of the three Great houses of powerful magicians: Chud', Lud' and Nav'.

The game, designed for 2-6 people and is built on the hard opposition players to each other. Diplomacy in the Regulations allows to conclude temporary alliances, but this only exacerbates the depth of conflict, because to win the struggle can only one Great House.

Secret City is a tactical and strategic game where the player must correctly distribute profits from the territories, buying the best mercenary, and accumulating magic energy for powerful spells. The basis of the gameplay are the Strategy - a special announcement at the beginning of the map, whose success depends on the player's army, spells that are on his hands and, of course, the actions of other participants.

item.description:
A board game about train barons and desperadoes in the Wild West. As a rail baron in the 1880's American West, you try to expand your railroad empire by moving goods and passengers between cities. You may invest in new trains and stations or upgrade your trains to make them go faster and carry more goods. Buy goods where they are cheap and sell them where they fetch the best price. But beware: Gangs of desperadoes hired by rival rail barons will try to hold up and rob your trains, or blow up the tracks to derail you.

A roll-and-move game where you each turn will roll three dice; your large trains will move the sum of all the dice, your small trains the sum of the two highest dice and your gang of desperadoes the highest die. Pay to pick up goods in cities (small trains may carry one good while large trains may carry two) or pick up passengers for free. Deliver goods and passengers to the cities accepting them, your profit will depend on how far you moved the goods. Goods available for buying and selling are fixed for the different cities and prices are pre-printed on the board. If an opponent's train pass your gang of desperadoes you will rob the train if you roll higher on a die than your opponent does (trains cannot change direction and are forced to use the entire die roll and hence you can maneuver to force them into your ambush). Other features are "telegrams" (a la community chest cards), marshals and sticks of dynamite...

The goal of the game is to be the first to reach a given number of "success points" (victory points), which you get for buying trains and stations and for cash in hand.

item.description:
Welcome to Mega-City One, a city of over four hundred million people and every one of them a potential criminal. Stretching the length of the 22nd Century North American eastern seaboard, Mega-City One is the most dangerous city on Earth – a serious crime takes place every second of every day. This is a city so dangerous that it demands a special breed of law enforcer. Here, there are no police, no trials and no juries – there are only the judges. It takes fifteen years to train a judge for life on the streets of Mega-City One.ï»¿

"Judge Dredd" is a 28mm miniatures skirmish game designed to be quick, easy to learn, and capable of handling the madness that is Mega-City One, from the powerful judges to the lowliest punk or mutant.

Players take turns moving figures and taking actions. Figures can be customized to use a multitude of weapons, equipment and powers - running, jumping, driving, and fighting in a crazy sci-fi themed world. You create the scenarios and take it from there.

May your Lawgiver always fire true!

Note This game is the spiritual successor of Gangs of Mega-City One (GoMC1) but it is a different game. It is compatible with the models from Mongoose Publishing.

item.description:
From the game's website: The first player to the 100-point target wins. Each round all players get 7 new letter cards. A die is rolled to determine the length of the word that will score points in that round. (Ex. If a 4 is rolled, only 4-letter words score points that round.) Roll a bull’s-eye, and the roller gets to determine that round’s word length.

Each letter card has a value attached to it. Some special letter cards have a range of values (Ex. 0 - 2) where a player gets to choose the value (0, 1 or 2) if that card can be used in a word. Playing at the same time, using their own cards, players have one minute to make a word of the determined length for that round.

At the end of each round, players advance their tokens by the number of points in the word they made, starting with the player who rolled the die. Choose carefully. Your highest-scoring word isn’t always your best choice. There are consequence targets on the board (red - always beneficial; black - take a chance) that can help you get to the final goal fastest. Land on a target - take the consequence. Making the best use of these targets is the key to winning.

item.description: A player has five seconds to memorize a specific shade of color. He then tries to match it to the same color on one of the color wheels. The first player to make six matches wins.

This is a rummy-style game. Players play from and then replenish their hands of cards. The goal is to be the first player to play five volcano cards. You obtain and play a volcano card when you discard three different precursor cards from your hand simultaneously. Meanwhile, various action cards played by you and the other players can help or hinder your progress.

item.description:
This game is for 4 players, playing as partners.

Each card has a value from 1 to 48. The four Aces are excluded from this and are called Muettes (the French word for Mute). Each player can bid which is really a search for a trump sequence. An example of bidding could be 'All the red cards' or '7s to 9s'. The only restriction in the bidding is that a legal bid must be at least 2 cards and no more than 24 cards. Once established, the hand is played. Note that there is no following suit, you can play any card in your hand to a trick and that the partnership, that won the bid, can nominate that each trick will be played High or Low (all tricks will be won by the highest ranked card or that each trick will be won by the lowest ranked card).
I understand that one year after the release of the game, the author published a revised set of rules which customers could collect at their Parisian game's shop.

At the beginning of the 16th century, the city of Rouen is the main French port. The city's wealth depends on fishing and the trading of salted fish. Salt produced in the mines has to be loaded onto ships and used to preserve herring and cod fished in the Atlantic Ocean. Every week ships full of salt barrels leave Rouen for the fishing grounds of the Atlantic Ocean, and once back, the goods are sold in the city markets. The players represent city merchants, and they invest in ships and city buildings to try to get rich. Who will be the richest merchant of Rouen, when Francis I, King of France, comes to visit the City?

In Upon a Salty Ocean, players start the game with one caravel loaded with three salt barrels, a salt mine and 10-16 money. From this, they must build a shipping empire! The game lasts five turns, with each turn being divided into three phases.

In the event phase, players adjust prices on the market based on the current event tile, take into the account the weather and environmental conditions that will affect them the remainder of the round, and reveal the event tile for the subsequent round.

The action phase lasts a variable number of rounds depending on how many actions players want to take and can afford. Eight actions are available and they're divided into four types:


 City: (1) buy a saline and (2) buy a building
 Navigation: (1) travel to the ocean and fish and (2) travel to Rouen
 Harbor: (1) build a ship and (2) move goods
 Market: (1) sell to the market and (2) buy from the market


On a player's turn, he can take any one of the either actions or pass; the cost of an action is the number of times this type of action has been performed previously during this round. For example, the first use of a City action costs 0, while the next use (whether to buy a saline or a building) costs 1. A player who passes can take an action later in the same phase. The action phase ends once all players pass. A player can go into debt during a turn, paying one coin in interest when doing so; as long as the player is in the black once the action round ends (by selling to the market), no further payment is due.

In the turn end phase, players produce salt, may use special buildings, pay interest (if needed), reset the cost of the actions to zero, and so on. A player can have no more than 40 coins at the end of a turn unless he owns a banque, and the limit is 80 coins without owning Salle des Coffres. This limit is important as the player with the most coins after five rounds wins. Some buildings provide endgame bonuses to which the coin limit doesn't apply.

item.description:
PRAWDA CZY WYZWANIE (TRUTH OR DARE) is one of the most popular party games ever. Its prototype consisted of bottle gaming, and challenging or asking chosen players some kind of embarrassing questions.

 
In the card version of the game the players finally have a possibility to choose the task, and a random person who decides to speak the truth or take the challenge. They may choose from a pool of over 300 questions and over 100 challenges presented on the cards. The game also allows some space for inventing your own questions.
 Extra rules and an option of a reward for the winner makes the game dynamic and exciting! Additional tasks and duels make the game even more fun. Another thing is the special cards which you can shuffle into the main deck. They give you the possiblity of changing the questions, or even asking players about the details of their previous answers, or force everyone in a current round to take a challenge!

item.description:
Theme: Approaching the Apocalypse, the various factions of the occult world accelerate their struggles to achieve their ancestors goals.
 The Nephilim are waking up in mass and prepare to return to their previous state of mind magic ... The Templars organized to implement the Grand Plan and declare war on the Nephilim and Selenim.
 The Selenim leave their kingdoms, these extraterrestrials dimensionsthey are the masters, and work vigorously for the recreation of the Black Moon and the advent of a dark age that one can bring the Apocalypse.
 The Mysteries, the occult societies, born when the world was young and when the Nephilim were running free all over the world, leave the shadows and confront the other factions at the approach of the Apocalypse.
 The time has come!

Goal: 
You win the game, either by obtaining the number of victory points defined early in the game, either by eliminating all the bases or opponents without having the opportunity to put new bases in game on the next turn.
 Once the game starts, the victory points are obtained in two ways:
 Each opponent base destroyed gives 1 victory point .
 A successful mission saves 2 to 5 points of victory, according to its difficulty.
 Once fixed the number of victory points , the game can begin ...
Game play: the first stage of the game is to place a base on the table. This base will be the starting point for the operations of your characters. once it's done, you may put characters in play, and they will act thereafter. Your network grows by the involvement of new bases that will cause more characters.
 Once brought into play, a character can take action. Thus, we can equip, prepare magical operations, playing a special action card, be a ship for a mission or a mission to intercept enemy, etc..

item.description:
Visit all of Fancy Nancy's favorite spots, collecting Souvenir Tokens as you go. When your luggage is covered with mementos of where you've been, race home as fast as you can. The first one home is the winner.

Encourages simple decision making and strategic thinking; visual interpretation and social skills.

Game contains 1 Board, 1 Spinner, 4 Fancy Nancy Game Pieces, 4 Suitcase Boards, and 16 Souvenir Tokens.

Age 5 and up.

2-4 players take turns influencing a central character in an attempt to end each chapter of her life to their advantage. The several mechanics that drive the game; playing color-based scenery cards in connection to her location, drawing tokens with positive or negative words on them, and taking 'characterized' actions -will all be used by the players to tell the story as it happens. Whichever player's decisions had the strongest influence on the story, wins!

Nova was a sentient alien scientist, and he had made a startling, grave discovery; the galaxy he had called home was also home to an imminent supernova, about to wipe out life as they knew it. Many of the animals in the galaxy were not sentient; they would have no way of surviving on their own. So he established a team for the preservation of alien life. Jumping from planet to planet in a race against a star about to explode, they sought to gather these aliens into a space vehicle that could carry them all to safety. They called it Nova’s Ark…

This is a light cooperative game for 2-7 players which plays in about 15-20 minutes; it also features a solitaire variant.

There are 72 cards in the deck in sets of 2, 3, 4 or 5; a player starts his turn by drawing a set of cards equal to the number of players. This player chooses a card, and passes the cards around the table, so that there are a dwindling number of choices. As players collect sets, these are played in to clear space in a player's hand. Each player has a hand-limit of 5 cards. If any player exceeds the number of cards he can hold, the team is defeated. If all 72 cards are either held (without exceeding hand-limit) or presented in sets, all players win.

MICROBADGE NOW ABAILABLE!
 Nova's Ark Fan

item.description:
Boy Crazy is a simple collectible card game for girls, created by Decipher Inc. during the Pokémon Trading Card Game boom.

Cards are distributed in packs of 9 cards. Each card featured a picture of a boy aged 12–22, his first name, set of statistics about him (height, date of birth, color of eyes), and a list of his likes and dislikes. Cards includes boys from across the United States, from different ethnic backgrounds and hair and eye colors, including disabled boys.

Game is basically a very simple matchmaking game. Minimum requirements for game are at least 9 cards, and each player should have pencil and paper. Play begins when players decide who gets to go first. Using the Boy Crazy cards (9 cards or more), first player secretly writes down which boy she likes best and why. Then the first player lays out the cards so everyone can see them. The other players try to make a match by writing who they think is the best boy for the first player and why. Then, each of the other players take turns revealing who they chose as her match. After the first player reveals her response, scores are tabulated for that round. Each player who correctly matches the first player's response scores a point. Play continues until every girl has a chance for her friends to guess her match. To start a new round players should discard starting set of 9 cards and draw a new set of 9 cards. The player or players who makes the most correct guesses wins.

The game was so popular that Decipher launched a companion "Boy Crazy" magazine in September 2001.

A trick-taking game for traditional playing cards. Features 'boasting' - a push-your-luck mechanic.

Each round, an auction is held for the right to be 'big fish', who will have a better hand and should win more tricks than any little fish. Unlike other card games, you bid points of your score - being a big fish carries a greater element of risk, since you need to regain at least the points you just lost in the auction.

A game lasts around 4-6 rounds, decided in advance. For 2 players, 4 rounds are recommended.

summary of a round:
- DEAL 6 cards to each player. Deal out a face-up 'dummy hand' of 6 cards.

- Have an AUCTION for the right to be big fish. The winning bid is deducted from the big fish's score.

- BIG FISH declares the trump suit, then exchanges any number of cards from their hand with cards from the extra hand.

- Each player BOASTS how many tricks they will win.

- Starting with Big Fish, PLAY out the 6 tricks. There is no need to follow suit and the first-played suit has no special significance.

- Players who took fewer tricks than their boast win nothing. Players who win at least as many as their boast SCORE points equal to their boast squared.

El Mundo de Águila Roja (The World of Red Eagle) is a collectable card game based on the popular TV series of Águila Roja, a success of TVE (Televisión Española) and the producer Globomedia. The TV serie present the adventures of a avenging hero with martial arts training in the spanish XVII century.

The game has been designed by Globomedia and developed by a group of experts in collectable card games directed by Omar Sagol and Joel Calafell.

The basic collection includes 154 cards with the places, characters and more emblematic events of the TV series. The game is based on four factions, each one of as it has his own thematic deck and way to get the victory:

- The manipulative Clergy
- The worker People
- The powerful Royalty
- The dark Conspirators.

The players must build a deck of 40 cards of his faction and neutral cards. This cards are played over the table to attack, defend, travel and activate special powers. The first player that reach 25 (or more) victory points and keep this avantage for one turn, will be the winner.

The games comes in 3 presentations:

- Starter Decks: with 2 ready-to-play decks. Each set presents 2 decks:"Conspirator & Royalty" and "Town & Clergy".
- Theme Decks: with one of the four factions in 56 cards decks.
- Booster Packs: with assorted 5 cards in common, uncommon and rare type card.


El Mundo de Aguila Roja es un Juego de Cartas Coleccionable (JCC) basado en la famosa serie de televisión española, ambientada en el siglo XVII y que narra las aventuras de un justiciero vengador con entrenamiento de artes marciales.

En este juego, los jugadores pueden escoger a que bando pertenecer: el Clero manipulador, la poderosa Casa Real, los oscuros Conspiradores o el trabajador Pueblo. Los jugadores deberán preparar un mazo de 40 cartas compuestas de Sucesos, Personajes y Lugares que irán jugando sobre la mesa para viajar, atacar, defenderse y activar habilidades especiales.

Cada bando tiene diferentes formas de conseguir la victoria que se consigue cuando uno de los jugadores alcanza 25 puntos o más y se mantiene victorioso un turno.

El juego viene en 3 presentaciones:

- Set de Iniciación para 2 jugadores. Cada set con 2 barajas "Conspiradores y Casa Real" y "Pueblo y Clero"
- Baraja temática: con cada una de las 4 facciones en barajas de 56 cartas.
- Sobres de refuerzo: con 5 cartas cada uno (rara, infrecuente y comunes).

item.description:
Publisher Introduction Game Overview:

This comprehensive play aid includes all the rules, updated with current errata, diagrams and detailed examples of frequently asked questions, as well as all of the encounters for the popular Malifaux skirmish game in an easily referenced compact form.

Are you willing to risk your soul for a chance at great wealth and power? It's your only weapon in a world rife wtih monsters, necropunks, man-machine hybrids, gunslingers, and power-hungry politicos. In Malifaux, you lead your crew in the battle for control of the Breach, a dark portal to a world of limitless magic. Those who don't make it become monsters you must destroy.

Malifaux is a character-driven 32mm tabletop miniatures game. Players lead groups, called Crews, in skirmish attacks against their opponents in the magical realm of Malifaux. Players collect, build, and paint models representing the denizens of Malifaux and pit these Crews against one another. Masters, powerful practitioners of magic, and those fighting them control these Crews.

Masters can manipulate the course of events in the world around them, and can change their own fates, through their control or theft of the powerful Soulstones in Malifaux. A Crew conssists of a variety of fantastic and frightening beings, collectively known as Minions, who serve the Master as fodder in his or her machinations. In addition, Henchmen can lead specialized Crews in their Master's absence, or serve their Master directly as a member of a Crew. Masters and Henchmen are also supported by Totems, extension of their magical abilities which increase their spellcasting range and provide additional aid in an Encounter.

How well a Crew carries out its leader's Strategy and Schemes determiens whether or not it will emerge victgorious in an Encounter with an enemy Crew. Strategies represent the Crew's main path to victory, while Schemes are simpler alternate routes to achieve the leader's goals.

Malifaxu players use decks of cards called Fate Decks to resolve game events such as attacking and spell casting. Players can manipulate the cards they play to alter the Duel's outcome. It takes a shrewd leader to effectively utilize a Crew's resources, ensuring he or she always has ready the cards needed to Cheat Fate.

Be Prepared to fight to the death because Malifaux is the end of the line!

Four in a Row 3D! is a great two player game where both players try to make four in a row with their rings (one color for each of them). The first one to get four identical color beads in a row wins. This game is the same as the classic four in a row game except this time it is back in a new 3D form, 4x4x4 grid to add a new edge to the game. There is also an 5x5x5 version (see picture).

item.description: This puzzle puts brain versus brain in the spot light. All around the red sun! In this game, two players must face off with each other. Each gets two pegs to use. Players take turn moving a peg from one of the holes to the other. The first player to make it so the other cannot move loses and will not get the glory of the red sun! It is a think quick act quick game. The rules do not allow for time to think and strategize. You must be on your toes and always think one step ahead!

Compañeros is a trick-taking game that includes six colored suits of cards, each numbered 1 through 10. In the game, you use as many suits as the number of players participating.

Shuffle the cards, place a number of cards equal to the number of players face up on the table, then deal the remainder of the cards evenly amongst the players.

The starting player opens the trick by playing any card of his hand. The other players follow by playing any card from their hand. (Players are not obligated to match suit, and the game uses no trump.) After each player has played to the trick, the players add up the individual card values for each suit (color) separately.

The trick is won by the player(s) who have played a card in the color with the highest total. The player who played the highest card in that color gets to choose all cards of a color of his choice from the cards in the middle and keeps them as victory points. Then, the player with the second highest card in that color gets to choose, etc. Finally, the cards that were played during the trick are placed in the middle of the table for the next trick. If two or more colors are tied with high value, then no one who played in those colors (or any colors with a lower sum) scores any cards.

Once all nine tricks have been played, players add up the values of the cards they won during the game. The player with the highest total wins.

item.description:
Players herd their sheep around the board to collect Clover Tiles and also score bonus points for completing sentences. This game teaches children educational skills such as forming basic sentences and completing sets. The game play involves light strategy and also allows children to practice early reading and simple math.

Publisher's Description:
A Grammar Game Your Family will Flock To

Collect the clovers with your sheep to form sentences. Score with each subject, verb, adjective, and object. You’ll laugh at the wacky sentences you create!

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Early Vocabulary, Strategy, Basic Sentence Structure
